description:
Many of our beneficiaries whom we have come across in the last few months are struggling with their day-to-day expenses as their employers are trying to keep their businesses afloat due to the ongoing #COVID19 situation. Social workers from Student Care @ Children’s Society have since started an initiative where training and job opportunities will be put together on a weekly basis for those who need help. This list will also be shared across all our 12 service centres. ➡️ To view the list, please visit our Telegram channel t.me/sgchildrensoc.

Please share this resource with anyone who needs it! ❤️ If you come across any training or job opportunities that you think are suitable, please email Ms Lee Poh Ling at pllee@childrensociety.org.sg.

#SGUnited #SGTogether #staysafe

description: Happy Vesak Day! Wishing all our Buddhist friends, colleagues and supporters peace and happiness always. 😊

Many face stress as isolation, job prospects and family woes worsen as the #COVID19 continues to spread globally. ⁣
⁣
However, as a society, we need foster hope for everyone to soldier on. Hope, is what keeps us going. Hoping that when we help one another, we can move forward with courage and confidence. The effects of COVID-19 are far from over and we foresee more families in need facing greater challenges. ⁣
⁣
While we are actively connecting with our beneficiaries impacted by COVID-19, we call for your support to sustain our efforts to provide meals, daily necessities, and most importantly, emotional and psychological support. ⁣
⁣
Your donation will help us greatly, especially during this time of crisis. Click link in bio to find out more on how your donations can help. ⁣
⁣
#SGUnited #SingaporeTogether #BeTheirHope

description:
As our drop-in centre JYC @ Children’s Society has temporarily closed due to the ongoing #COVID19 pandemic, our social workers and counsellors have been actively connecting with the children and youth. This is to ensure that they are coping well with their #HomeBasedLearning routine and that they can still open up and talk to us despite the current situation. The staff at the Centre also delivered refurbished laptops to beneficiaries to assist them during this period. ⁣
⁣
Our beneficiaries have expressed their desires to return to the Centre as many of them see the Centre as their place of solace. JYC @ Children’s Society asks for your continued support to keep their current efforts going, and the need to step up support in the coming months. Support them by clicking the link in our bio.
⁣
Come what may, let’s continue to look ahead with hope!

#SGUnited #SingaporeTogether #staysafe #stayhome #stayhomeforSG #sgchildrensociety

description:
As our drop-in centre JYC @ Children’s Society has temporarily closed due to the ongoing #COVID19 pandemic, our social workers and counsellors have been actively connecting with the children and youth. This is to ensure that they are coping well with their #HomeBasedLearning routine and that they can still open up and talk to us despite the current situation. The staff at the Centre also delivered refurbished laptops to beneficiaries to assist them during this period. ⁣
⁣
Our beneficiaries have expressed their desires to return to the Centre as many of them see the Centre as their place of solace. JYC @ Children’s Society asks for your continued support to keep their current efforts going, and the need to step up support in the coming months. Support them by clicking the link in our bio.

Come what may, let’s continue to look ahead with hope!

description:
Ms Ann Hui Peng, Director of Student Service @ Children’s Society, spoke to Channel 8 regarding the rise in the number of calls and chats our Tinkle Friend service has received since the #COVID19 #CircuitBreaker measures have been set in place.

Some of the issues that the children have shared with #TinkleFriend include being worried about their families’ financial situation as their family members may have lost their jobs and unhappiness due to difficulties in adjusting to #HomeBasedLearning.

Catch the interview at tinyurl.com/8world-tinklefriend
labels_str: person human toy chair furniture wood

description: Some of Singapore Children’s Society’s staff members spoke to @zaobaosg regarding the rise in number of children seeking help and advice from Tinkle Friend. Ms Ann Hui Peng, Director, Student Service @ Children’s Society noted that more children are inclined to use online chat as compared to phone calls when they talk to Tinkle Friend. Ms Xing Yating, Counsellor, Student Service @ Children’s Society shared that the issues these children share about include their examination results and relationships with their peers. She noted that there has been an increase of callers sharing issues they may face during home-based learning such as internet connectivity issues and the absence of an adult assisting them with online research. Ms Lin Xiaoling, Deputy Director, Advocacy and Research Department advised parents to take note of children’s emotions during this period as they may feel unsettled due to the changes to their routines. Read more here: tinyurl.com/zaobao-tinklefriend

description:
As the #COVID19 pandemic rages, lives and routines are disrupted as we try to get used to the "new normal". Do you know our children are having these big feelings too?

If your child needs a listening ear, Tinkle Friend will be here. Your child can call Tinkle Friend helpline at 1800 2744 788 from Mondays to Fridays, 2.30pm to 5pm. Tinkle Friend online chat service is available at www.tinklefriend.sg from Mondays to Thursdays, 2.30pm to 7pm, and on Fridays, from 2.30pm to 5pm.

If you need any resources on how caregivers can address the anxiety that children are facing, please visit tinyurl.com/resources-covid19

#ParenTIPS #SGUnited #letsfightthevirus

⁣
Some of the cries for help include financial issues due to unemployment, school closures, and not being able to afford devices and data for Home-based Learning. Even our national helpline for children Tinkle Friend has also received calls from children who are distressed due to the ongoing #COVID19 situation. ⁣
⁣
Let’s all do what we can to help our children, youth and families which are badly affected by this pandemic. #SGUnited #SingaporeTogether⁣

Start helping our beneficiaries today. Link in bio.

description:
Mr Chee Thow Wei Liat, Assistant Director/Head, VOX @ Children’s Society, spoke to Mediacorp Channel 8 on the impact of COVID-19 on the youth-at-risk. As the centre currently limits the number of youth dropping in due to the COVID-19 situation, he noted that some youth will loiter around public areas such as carparks and void decks. He is concerned that these youth may end up mixing with friends whom may influence them to take drugs or play truant. The Centre is currently using social media platforms to continue their engagement with youth.

Catch the interview at tinyurl.com/covid19vox and follow @vox.44c on Instagram to find out more!

description: Our child sexual abuse prevention programme, KidzLive: I Can Protect Myself, marks its 20th year of empowering children with body safety skills. We can all play a part in teaching our children to keep themselves safe.🛡️ Take a read to see how the programme has evolved over the years - link is in our bio!

description:
Want to gain first-hand experience in organising events to champion a social cause?⁣
⁣
You can do so now if you sign up for the @citiymcayouthforcauses, a community initiative started by Citi and the YMCA of Singapore in 2003. This programme provides youths aged 15 to 25 with a platform to learn lessons outside of the classrooms to spark their entrepreneurial spirit, and be developed into socially responsible community leaders.⁣
⁣
To sign up, please contact Ms Cherlyn Ang at cang@childrensociety.org.sg or at 6273 2010 by Sunday, 12 April 2020. ⁣
⁣
Gather your friends and kickstart a project together for a good cause now!

description:
Other than providing love and care to our children and youth beneficiaries, our Society also works closely with low-income families who struggle to get by their days. Our family service centre based in Yishun, attends to families from all walks of life, and some who are in need of assistance to make ends meet. ⁣
⁣
Let’s have Lai Sum, one of our social workers from Yishun Family Service @ Children’s Society, tell you more about the amazing work they do! ⁣
⁣
Visit this link to watch the rest of the video > tinyurl.com/yishunfs
labels_str: person human advertisement poster

description:
Parenting methods can differ as long as they meet the needs of children. What do you think are the foremost important ones? In this video, Dr Elliott shares his thoughts on the definite needs of children. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
This is the last of a three-part series containing the highlights of our 13th Singapore Children's Society Lecture that was delivered by Dr John M. Elliott on 12 October last year. Dr Elliott passed away on 13 December 2019. He was an academic with a deep interest in the social and cognitive development of young children, and retired as the Associate Professor in the Department of Psychology at the National University of Singapore. ⁣Dr Elliott was a long-standing volunteer with Children’s Society, and served as the Chairman of its Research Committee for close to 20 years. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Read the full lecture transcript: tinyurl.com/13thSCSLectureTranscript ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
#ParenTIPS ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Music credits: ⁣⁣
Carefree by Kevin MacLeod. Link: incompetech.filmmusic.io/song/3476-carefree ⁣⁣
License: creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/
labels_str: advertisement poster flyer brochure paper person human female teen girl people

description:
What are the important factors for building children’s resilience to adversity? In this series, we looked at whether close relationships with caregiver protects children against the negative impact of Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACEs) on their social emotional skills.

To find out more, please view the February issue of Research Bites at tinyurl.com/ResearchBitesFeb2020

#ParenTIPS

description:
Parenting resources commonly regard the idea of parental warmth as an important part of a parent-child relationship. But does parental warmth equate parental concern? In this video, Prof Elliott unpacks the difference between the two, and uncovers a distinct trait of Asian and Western parents.

This is part two of a three-part series containing the highlights of our 13th Singapore Children's Society Lecture that was delivered by Dr John M. Elliott on 12 October last year. Dr Elliott passed away on 13 December 2019. He was an academic with a deep interest in the social and cognitive development of young children, and retired as the Associate Professor in the Department of Psychology at the National University of Singapore. Dr Elliott was a long-standing volunteer with Children’s Society, and served as the Chairman of its Research Committee for close to 20 years.

Read the full lecture transcript: tinyurl.com/13thSCSLectureTranscript

#ParenTIPS

Music credits: 
Carefree by Kevin MacLeod Link: https://incompetech.filmmusic.io/song/3476-carefree 
License: http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/

Thank you, John, for making a trip down to our youth drop-in centre JYC @ Children’s Society to present a copy to us.

Want to get some tips on how to be successful in your love life and do charity at the same time? You can do so now if you purchase the book from www.localbooks.sg. $3 will be donated to Singapore Children’s Society for every book sold.

Let us join hands 🤝 in helping to care and support our children, youth and families in need today.

description: Your children must have heard about the COVID-19 virus and some of them may be feeling anxious or fearful. They should wear a surgical mask only if they feel unwell and have respiratory symptoms like a cough or a runny nose. *The Tinkle Friend service is manned by trained volunteers and our staff members who provide support, advice, and information to lonely and distressed children, especially in situations when their parents or main caregivers are unavailable.

description:
Every parent wants to raise their children well. They seek tips in different resources, ranging from online parenting articles to parenting books. Yet, many of these parenting resources are from the West, and some may even carry conflicting advice. How can parents decide which is the best way to raise their child?

This is part one of a three-part series containing the highlights of our 13th Singapore Children's Society Lecture that was delivered by Dr John M. Elliott on 12 October last year. Dr Elliott passed away on 13 December 2019. He was an academic with a deep interest in the social and cognitive development of young children, and retired as the Associate Professor in the Department of Psychology at the National University of Singapore. Dr Elliott was a long-standing volunteer with Children’s Society, and served as the Chairman of its Research Committee for close to 20 years.

Read the full lecture transcript: tinyurl.com/13thSCSLectureTranscript

#ParenTIPS

description:
In view of the COVID-19 (Coronavirus Disease 2019) situation, Singapore Children’s Society has rolled out preventive measures to ensure the well-being of our staff members, volunteers, visitors and beneficiaries. Do remember to practise good personal hygiene and take care of your health too! ⁣
⁣
We would also like to strongly urge our well-wishers to continue supporting us despite the circumstance we are facing. ⁣
⁣
Support us by making an online donation today to help our children, youth and families in need. All donations are entitled to a 250% tax-deduction. Take action now: tinyurl.com/singaporechildrenssociety ⁣
⁣
#letsfightthevirus #COVID19
labels_str: person human

description:
#casestory 
Being pregnant is not easy at all. It gets tougher when you have no income, your husband is incarcerated, and you are constantly on the move with no proper roof over your head. You have another child to feed too, but she ran away from home after failing PSLE. That was what Mdm Sara* experienced. 
At her wits' end, she turned to Yishun Family Service @ Children’s Society where our social worker assisted with her finances and secured a HDB rental flat for her family. 
Mdm Sara would not have pulled through the difficult time without our social worker’s support. Feeling hopeful for the future, Mdm Sara said: “I have achieved more than what I expected. Thank you, Singapore Children’s Society.” *Name has been changed to protect the identity of our beneficiary.
labels_str: desk furniture table person human toy computer electronics laptop pc

description:
Every child needs a listening ear. If you would like to play a part in supporting children in need, sign up to be a Tinkle Friend volunteer at www.childrensociety.org.sg/volunteer-join.

Tinkle Friend is a national toll-free helpline (1800 2744 788) and online chat (www.tinklefriend.sg) for all primary-school-aged children in Singapore. Tinkle Friend provides support, advice, and information to lonely and distressed children, especially in situations when their parents or main caregivers are unavailable.

description: We wish all our friends and supporters a prosperous and joyous Chinese New Year! May this holiday be the start towards success. 😀
labels_str: text label interior design indoors

description:
Food brings people together. Especially during Chinese New Year, reunion dinner reaffirms the love and respect that bind families together. While many enjoy that bliss, there are others who are separated from their families, much less having proper food on a daily basis. ⁣
⁣
While preparing the red packets this year, would you consider an additional one for our beneficiaries? #kindness #cnygiving ⁣
⁣
Click on the link in our bio to find out more 😊
labels_str: text

description:
Being an upstander in a bullying episode is akin to being a hero: a hero that will stand up against bullies. When an upstander sees or hears someone being bullied, they act immediately to provide help and support to the victim.

Since this is the start of a school year, some of you might want to start to promote a Bully-Free learning environment in your school. Swipe left to find out more on how you can be an upstander!

For more information, check out our website at www.bullyfree.sg

#bullyfreesg #childrensociety #antibullying

⁣⁣
Contact Ms Grace Teo at hlteo@childrensociety.org.sg to request for donation envelopes today so that you can start the brand new year with A Little Kindness, Lots of Joy!

Click on the link in our bio for more information.

description:
Our community mothers of Yishun Family Service @ Children’s Society (also known as Wondermummies) gathered for a Christmas party and photo exhibition together with their family earlier this month.

Our mothers wished upon a Christmas tree to share their hopes for their children. The families also shared magical moments seeing their mothers as models of the exhibition. We hope that the process of the photoshoot, photo exhibition and sharing of blessings empower our mothers to see themselves in a different light.

description:
"Christmas is not as much about opening our presents as opening our hearts.” - Janice Maeditere 
As we celebrate Christmas today, let’s open our hearts and minds and think about giving to the less fortunate. Have a Merry Christmas with your family and friends!
labels_str: dinner supper food meal turkey dinner roast plant

description:
Living in a cramped rental flat while sustaining on a diet of instant noodles and canned food, the Tans’* everyday life is a common reality for many of our beneficiaries, who fall into financial distress in many ways.

While you are doing your Christmas shopping, we humbly ask that you keep the children, youth and families of Singapore Children’s Society in your thoughts as there are many families like the Tans who need your help to get back on their feet. 
Donate and help change lives at www.1000p.org.sg/get-involved *Names have been changed to protect the beneficiaries’ identities.
labels_str: face person human boy head man hair

description:
Are you counting down to Christmas and the New Year? Before this year ends, it’s nice to look back on how you’ve made a difference to others. ⁣
⁣
Watch the testimonials of our ex-beneficiaries where they speak about how our social workers have impacted their lives. It is heartwarming to know that our children and youth are doing well after they have left our centres. #givingback ⁣
⁣
Click the link in our bio to watch more, as we have included a heartwarming surprise in it. 😀 #SurpriseTheirChristmas

description:
Our children beneficiaries from Student Care @ Children's Society and their parents gathered for a year-end celebration that was uniquely different this year with games such as bowling and a dance performance choreographed by the children themselves.

Taking a leaf from the Mr Men and Little Miss series, each child was given unconventional awards such as 'Miss Positive' and ‘Mr Honest’. This was to celebrate the success of every child as well as affirm them and their parents of the strengths displayed by their child in the year 2019.

description:
Our youth beneficiaries from JYC @ Children’s Society played a part in organising a bonding day for tutors and tutees under Project T, a programme under the Youth Executive Committee of Jurong Spring Community Club as part of YouthGIG 2019.

The bonding day included a trip to the Trick Eye Museum where they took many interactive pictures together followed by a hands-on session back at the centre where they used air clay to mould into bird figurines. Lunch was an eventful event as they got to create their own Thai salad.

Mr Desmond Lee, Minister for Social and Family Development & Second Minister for National Development as well as Member of Parliament for the Jurong GRC also visited the youth at the centre and interacted with them.

YouthGIG is an annual event where youth from JYC @ Children’s Society help to organise, plan and execute a project to give back to the community.
labels_str: clothing apparel person human shorts pants sleeve

description:
The favourite month of the year is finally here again! In the spirit of Christmas, we have gathered some of our ex-beneficiaries for a chat, and find out how they have been doing. It is always nice to know how the work that we do have impacted our children and youth. That’s what keeps us going as well! ⁣
⁣
Check out the video with the link in our bio, as we have included a very heartwarming surprise! 😊 #SurpriseTheirChristmas #giveback ⁣
⁣
Support our campaign by clicking the link in our bio!

description:
At the 4th Singapore Children’s Forum this morning themed “Why is it sometimes not fair?”, we delved into the world of 25 children and youth who shared their perception on what unfairness and inequality looks like from their lenses.

Attendees were invited to first catch a film that was specially produced for this forum entitled “INequality”, before joining in a discussion with five distinguished guest panellists. Thank you Assoc Prof @muhammadfaishalibrahim for joining us today. We hope you had a good morning of insightful conversations like we did!
labels_str: person human clothing apparel sitting shorts

Attendees were invited to first catch a film that was specially produced for this forum entitled “INequality”, before joining in a discussion with five distinguished guest panellists. Thank you Assoc Prof @muhammadfaishalibrahim for joining us today. We hope you had a good morning of insightful conversations like we did!

description:
Our youth delegate and adult mentor have spent an engaging and fulfilling past three days at the Asian Children’s Summit.

They participated in learning sessions and workshops on various thematic issues: children in the digital environment; climate change and the right to a healthy environment; children on the move and violence against children.

This morning, the Summit culminated in a dialogue with adults. The youth delegates presented their recommendations to representatives from the United Nations, ASEAN bodies, government officials and NGOs. This not only allowed them to raise awareness of issues and contribute to improved knowledge but ensured they can meaningfully participate in discussions and decisions that impact them.
 #TheAsiaIwant #ChildRightsAt30 #CRC30
labels_str: person human room indoors crowd cafeteria restaurant classroom school meal food furniture

description:
As this year marks the 30th anniversary of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child (UNCRC), there are celebrations all over the world to mark this occasion.

Our youth delegate and adult mentor from JYC @ Children’s Society are currently in Bangkok, Thailand to participate in the Asian Children’s Summit from 26 to 29 November 2019. They will be meeting other children and policy makers to discuss key issues that will impact their future including climate change and the digital environment.

Here are some pictures of the pre-summit study sessions with our other youths and snippets from Day 1 of the conference. Stay tuned for more! #TheAsiaIwant #ChildRightsAt30 #CRC30

description:
Thinking of activities to engage your child during this December holiday? 🤔

Join our KidzLive Parent-Child Programme where 4- to 6-year-old children will be empowered with body safety skills! Check out the poster for more details and sign up at https://tinyurl.com/SCSKidzLivePCP

This session will be held at our VOX @ Children's Society at Block 44 Chai Chee Street #01-108 Singapore 461044. See you there!

description:
Tonight, we had the honour of having our Patron-in-Chief President @halimahyacob grace our Charity Gala Dinner 2019, held at @shangrilasg.

Our guests were entertained by fantastic dance performances by our beneficiaries and @stepupsingapore and song performances by singer @jeffhellomusic.

We hope that this event was meaningful to you, as it is to us. As always, thank you for your kind donations and support!

description:
We are happy to be part of @artbox_singapore this year, held at @sgturfclub. Our Society will be featuring our beneficiaries’ own art pieces, re-mastered by @diannaetc, a graphic illustrator! ⁣
⁣
Get hands-on with hydro dripping and create your very own exclusively designed horseshoe for only $20 when you come down to the Singapore Turf Club booth from 22 to 24 November, or you could make a donation at tinyurl.com/absg2019 to support our work today. ⁣
⁣
All proceeds from the sale of the hydro-dipped horseshoe will be donated to Singapore Children’s Society 😊

Our beneficiaries from VOX @ Children’s Society will be putting up an exciting dance performance for our audience, which includes our Guest-of-Honour and Patron-in-Chief President Halimah Yacob at our upcoming #charitygaladinner on Friday, 22 November 2019! ⁣
⁣
Show them your support by clicking the link in our bio! ⁣
⁣
We believe that your support will serve as a huge encouragement for our children and youth to take bigger steps in life! 😊

description:
Is it possible to spend only $2.63 a day for all your meals? Our social workers embarked on this journey and took on the #livebelowtheline challenge for five days.

Now, it’s your turn! We invite you and your friends to join the challenge to experience being on a shoestring budget.

Tag a friend whom you want to do this challenge with, and share your journey with us by tagging us using #livebelowthelinewithSCS #EndPoverty

description:
Will you be eating at your favourite restaurant, or catching your favourite movie this weekend? Care to consider forgoing one of these little luxuries just this once, and donate to help our children who don’t even have a proper home or safe environment to live in? Give them a chance to dream as well. #supportchildreninneed #takeaction #donatenow

Support our campaign by clicking the link in bio, or visit tinyurl.com/childrensdaycampaign
labels_str: poster advertisement flyer brochure paper

description:
As the #livebelowtheline challenge draws to a close, we are reminded of how this is an everyday reality for some. There may not be a visible end to their challenge.

A single mother we support shares that she manages this reality by being grateful. She shares that without gratitude, one will never have enough no matter how much you have. In fact, this is the refrain many of our clients share. We have much respect for them as gratitude does not come naturally in scarcity.

This has been an exercise of empathy. As social workers, it has also provided us a glimpse into the struggles our beneficiaries experience. We dare not proclaim that we fully understand, but the five-day experience has taught us a whole lot of lessons. We are curious to know how this journey has impacted you. Let us know if you wish to give this a shot, as we would like to hear from you! #livebelowthelinewithSCS #EndPoverty
labels_str: bowl person human food toast french toast bread meal dish

description:
It was the GCE ‘N’ Level examination period when we were on the #livebelowtheline challenge. A single mother who came to our centre shared that she had no money left after paying for funeral expenses. All she could afford was instant noodles for her son and her own meals till she heads back to work the following week.

This is inequality that is invisible, as the youth would have to sit through national examinations, which may inevitability affect his future schooling or job prospects, with innutritious food had there not been help. He faces many challenges beyond himself, challenges often not measured by standardised tests. #livebelowthelinewithSCS #EndPoverty
labels_str: plant food dinner supper lunch meal vegetable

He faces many challenges beyond himself, challenges often not measured by standardised tests. #livebelowthelinewithSCS #EndPoverty

description: The lovely matriarch of a family of six managing on $1,600 of monthly salary informs that a family dinner would set her back $50 - $100 because she would have to “chip in”. She would make excuses to her sisters and brothers to avoid attending these gatherings because she simply couldn’t afford to. There is a sense of being alienated even from your own family, as she often had to say “no”. How does poverty affect socialisation and relationship building for the poor? We often feel excluded when we are unable to join colleagues and peers for meals, movies and gatherings. With the high costs of living in Singapore, recreational activities can be very expensive for middle-income families. What’s more for the low-income? Many of our beneficiaries tell us that they avoid going to the malls because “out of sight is out of mind”. Read on to find out our struggles as we stave off hunger pangs due to our limited food options in our #livebelowtheline challenge. #livebelowthelinewithSCS #EndPoverty
labels_str: food toast bread french toast

description: #casestory “I remembered an ex-beneficiary in his 50s who worked as a security guard. He would be tasked to work overtime whenever his colleagues were absent. He was happy to work another 10 -12 hours shift as this would mean extra income for his family of five. However, such last-minute arrangement would also mean that he would have to skip his dinner on those nights and go hungry till he reaches home the next morning after his shift. I never asked if there was a fridge or microwave oven at his workplace…” Many of our low-income beneficiary take up laborious jobs which require more energy but are they eating enough to sustain themselves? #livebelowtheline challenge #livebelowthelinewithSCS #EndPoverty
labels_str: fork cutlery plant food dish meal bread burger

description:
Our beneficiaries can fall into financial distress in many ways. Businesses fail, sole breadwinners fall sick or pass away and jobs are lost. These events are shocking, often without warning. Quality of life dips fast and the hope of returning to normal life can be distant. The adjustment can be emotionally difficult for these beneficiaries. Kids share that they are worried and afraid when they see the banks removing the television, or when they would need to use their ez-link cards to pay for meals. There are others that face loss and grief when a caretaker is no longer with them. It is a physical, social and psychological adjustment.

Read on to find out how we adjusted our mental, physical and emotional states as we undertake the #livebelowtheline challenge.

#livebelowthelinewithSCS #EndPoverty
labels_str: bowl person human plant food meal

description:
The #livebelowtheline challenge has taught us first-hand how mentally draining shopping on a shoestring budget can be. A tight budget is an everyday reality for some of our beneficiaries. A family of six we know reports their grocery budget to be $600 a month. That comes down to $3.33 per person a day, or $0.70 over our challenge budget. This means that the family often has to choose between paying for utilities or food.

We’ve begun having deeper conversations with our beneficiaries about their food budgets. “How do you do it? That’s a tight budget! What do you buy?”, we would ask. Eventually they share they do spend a little over what they usually report (hence arrears in utilities) but they dare not report a higher number when asking for assistance. They share that sometimes they are embarrassed or worried about a reporting a higher number when are asked why they ‘overspend’. We cannot help but wonder. How we can have deeper conversations with our beneficiaries about these topics in a safe, non-judgemental way? #livebelowthelinewithSCS #EndPoverty
labels_str: plant food produce vegetable

description:
Volunteers do not necessarily have the time; they just have the heart. To thank our volunteers for their invaluable contribution, we invited them to our annual Tribute to Volunteers event, where they mingled with fellow volunteers and staff members of Singapore Children’s Society while they enjoyed a sumptuous buffet brunch, followed by a movie screening.

We would like to say a BIG thank you to all our volunteers, and we hope to see you again next year! 😊

description:
17 October marks the International Day for the Eradication of Poverty. In 2015, the World Bank updated the international poverty line to be at US$1.90 PPP per day, and 736 million people in the world survive solely on that. To raise awareness, The Global Poverty Project @thegpp and The Oaktree Foundation @oaktreeau launched the #livebelowtheline challenge in 2010.

With this in mind, five social workers from Yishun Family Service @ Children’s Society took on the #livebelowtheline challenge to show our support to this initiative. It also gave them an opportunity to experience how some of the low-income families that we serve feel when they are on a shoestring budget. While Singapore does not have a poverty line, they have learnt so much from jumping on the #livebelowtheline bandwagon. Each of them relied solely on S$2.63* a day, over a period of five days for their meals.

Follow this space as we document the journey of our social workers on this challenge! If this is your jam (pun intended), swipe left to check out the rules of the challenge and feel free to TAG A FRIEND in the comments section below to jio them #livebelowthelinewithSCS #EndPoverty *Based on the conversion rate for the day for US$1.90.
labels_str: number text symbol label

description:
Our guest speaker, Dr John M. Elliott, spoke about ‘Parenting: Does one size fit all?’ at our 13th Singapore Children's Society Lecture at the Singapore Management University’s Mochtar Riady Auditorium this morning.

He discussed about the potential areas where there might be grounds to hesitate in accepting the standard textbook view of best practices in parenting. The lecture ended with a key message from Dr Elliott - Parents are their own best experts to guide their children. We hope you have had an insightful session like we did. See you next year!

Dr Elliott, who retired as Associate Professor from the National University of Singapore’s Department of Psychology in 2018, is an active volunteer with Children’s Society’s Research Committee over the last three decades.
labels_str: person human chair furniture screen electronics audience crowd indoors room projection screen classroom school speech lecture

description:
As we celebrate #ChildrensDay this October, let us not forget that there are some children out there who need our help. What are you waiting for? Pledge your support to bring relief and happiness to our children in need today. #supportchildreninneed #takeaction 
Support our campaign by clicking the link in bio, or visit tinyurl.com/childrensdaycampaign
labels_str: person human floor

description:
Do you know that in our society, we have children who are deprived of love and attention from their parents? Especially at a young age, these emotional needs are not to taken away from a child. Who can they turn to for help? ⁣
⁣
Just because you don’t see it, doesn’t mean it’s not happening. In this month of Children’s Day, show them that that are people around who cares. #childrensday #supportchildreninneed #takeaction ⁣
⁣
Support our campaign by clicking the link in bio, or visit tinyurl.com/childrensdaycampaign

description:
#ParenTIPS

We know that playing with our children is an effective way to build closer bonds with them.

The findings from our Infancy Study (https://tinyurl.com/SCSInfancyStudy) have also shown that children with closer bonds to their mothers had better social-emotional development as they grow up.

How can you better engage your child in play? Here are some ideas from the Department of Child Development at KK Women’s and Children’s Hospital!
labels_str: person human text advertisement poster flyer paper brochure

We all have a part to play in building a bully-free environment! While schools are doing their part in educating students on Cyber Wellness and Cyberbullying, it is also important and useful for parents to be equipped with the relevant knowledge.

Swipe left to find out more about Cyber Wellness and some interesting information about Cyberbullying.

For more information, check out our website www.bullyfree.sg

#bullyfreesg #childrensociety #antibullying

description:
Thank you @afccsg for having us! We were delighted to be part of a #afcc2019 panel discussion which dealt with difficult topics in children's literature such as child sexual abuse, childhood cancer, and depression.

To promote our book, Jun and the Octopus, we also conducted a workshop on using reading resources and storytelling to equip young children with body safety skills. We then had a "speed dating" session with educators to share more about the book, and how it can be used to empower children with body safety skills.

Grab your copy of Jun and the Octopus for $18 (before GST) at selected bookstores* or at our Bishan Office located at 9 Bishan Place #05-02 Junction 8 Office Tower Singapore 579837 today! :) *Stores include Books Kinokuniya, Huggs-Epigram Coffee Bookshop, and Woods in the Books

description:
Our 13th Singapore Children's Society Lecture speaker, Dr John M. Elliott, was interviewed by Lianhe Zaobao for his views on parenting.

Despite there being numerous parenting perspectives, Dr Elliott feels that parents should not simply subscribe to any one school of thought or be overly hung up on the labels of "east" and "west", slogans or teachings. Read the full Lianhe Zaobao interview at https://www.zaobao.com.sg/news/fukan/family/story20190916-989404

We are less than a month away from our 13th Lecture! 
It will be held on 12 October 2019, at SMU Administration Building, Mochtar Riady Auditorium from 10am to 12pm.

Have you registered yet? Registration link in bio!

description:
Are there best practices in parenting? How do parenting practices differ across Asian and Western cultures?

Dr John M. Elliott will be answering these questions and more at the 13th Singapore Children's Society Lecture, held on 12 October 2019, at SMU. 
Dr Elliott is an academic with a deep interest in the social and cognitive development of young children. He was an Associate Professor in the Department of Psychology at the National University of Singapore and he retired last year. He is also a long-standing volunteer with Singapore Children’s Society.

Check out the link in our bio to register your interest!
labels_str: book text handwriting bird animal

description:
We were pleasantly surprised and touched when Ms Meriam George, who came all the way from the United Kingdom, gave a generous donation of $1,000 and a handwritten note to support us and the work that we do.

An advocate for children's education, Ms George was inspired by her mother who was a dedicated teacher for four decades and an author of a children's book. “This donation is made in loving memory of my beloved mother, Mrs Noëlle George, who was a teacher for four decades and had taught the world to sing in perfect harmony,” said Ms George.

Thank you, Ms George, for your kind words, thoughts and gesture. Let us all continue to work together to bring relief and happiness to children, youth and families in need!

description:
VOX @ Children’s Society, @vox.44c is one of the four youth drop-in centres under Singapore Children’s Society.

Holding true to the values of Caring, Character, Competence, Confidence and Connection, our youths from VOX Café collaborated with guides from @dialogue.sg to serve beneficiaries from Filos Community Services.

Even though it was the youths’ first time working with their visually-impaired friends, they managed to communicate effectively and delivered a memorable lunch experience for the beneficiaries.

description:
“I am a single mother of 5 young children aged 1 to 11. It has been very tough for me being the only breadwinner of the family while caring for 5 younger children. I struggled to make ends meet for my children and hence approached Yishun Family Service @ Children's Society for help in 2017. 
My social worker Ms Kate Ofiaza helped me a lot. She has always been there to listen to my problems. With her help, I have also received food rations and school pocket money fund for my children. I have also benefited from the counselling sessions to work on my emotions whenever I have problems. I am really thankful to Ms Kate for her support all this while. She encourages me to be strong and helps to build up my self-confidence. I have become a happier and successful single mom for my children.” -Ms Noraiin, beneficiary from Yishun Family Service @ Children’s Society
labels_str: face person human glasses accessories accessory female smile

description:
Do you know of any child who does not attend pre-school because of family difficulties? ⁣
⁣
Each year, Singapore Children’s Society reaches out to children who are not registered in a pre-school centre yet and we support these families in enrolling their children to kick-start their educational journey. Follow our social worker Poh Ling, on her pre-school outreach visits as she knocks on doors to reach these households.

description:
#casestudy⁣
Anger is one letter short of danger, and no one is more aware of that than 13-year-old Michael*.⁣
⁣
When Michael first walked into RoundBox @ Children’s Society, his explosive temperament led his head first into heated arguments with his peers. Through a journey of engagement and psychotherapeutic interventions, our social workers helped him develop various skills and methods for emotional management.⁣
⁣
Gradually, Michael developed patience, and went on to challenge himself in other programmes such as the music band. Some of his achievements include performing for President Halimah Yacob as the lead vocalist of the RoundBox band.⁣
⁣
This Youth Day, we rejoice in the dreams, passions and talents of all youth, regardless of who they are.⁣
⁣
Help us bring out the potential of tomorrow’s leaders and innovators when you support Singapore Children’s Society. Would you like to be a part of this change? https://1000p.org.sg/get-involved⁣
⁣
*Name has been changed to protect the beneficiary’s identity.
labels_str: advertisement poster flyer brochure paper

description:
Singapore Children's Society conducted a research study together with KK Women's and Children's Hospital from 2007 to 2014 on caregiving arrangements for children in Singapore. We found that the type of main caregiver and the number of times the main caregiver changed had no influence on the child's temperament, attachment, or development. However, we found that babies with a closer bond with their mothers had better social-emotional skills at three years old.

For more details on these findings, please view the July issue of Research Bites at https://tinyurl.com/ResearchBitesJul2019 or read the newly published monograph at https://tinyurl.com/SCSInfancyStudy

#ParenTIPS by Singapore Children’s Society is a topical parenting series on trends and research concerning children and youth. Through this series, we hope that parents and caregivers can pick up useful ideas and information on how to support their children's well-being and help them thrive.

description:
#foodforthought Is it even possible to stretch $500 for a month in Singapore? Do you know that 55% of the individuals and families that we serve at Yishun Family Service @ Children’s Society are struggling with making ends meet with having less than $500 to spend each month?⁣
⁣
Here at Singapore Children’s Society, we work with families to promote stable family life and provide financial assistance through various programmes and services with the aim of helping families in need achieve independence, stability and resilience. Help our families in need today: https://1000p.org.sg/⁣
⁣
Photo credit: Pixabay

description:
Do you know that there is a small percentage of children entering Primary One each year without any form of pre-school education? Pre-school education lays the academic foundation for a child’s formal education.⁣
⁣
This is one of the days where our social worker Ms Chloe Aw, from Children Outreach @ Children’s Society, would follow-up on leads of families who have not registered their children in a pre-school yet, under our Pre-school Outreach programme. Working closely with Early Childhood Development Agency (ECDA), our social workers would visit these families to enquire about their children’s pre-school status and ensure that they receive the necessary assistance for a pre-school placement.

description:
We are excited to announce that our storybook ‘Jun and the Octopus’ was officially launched at @woodsinthebooks yesterday! The storybook was created to empower children with body safety skills to prevent sexual abuse. Our child beneficiaries from Student Care @ Children’s Society spent a meaningful afternoon listening to the author, Mr Goh Eck Kheng, who read them the book. 
For those interested in getting a copy, ‘Jun and the Octopus’ is for sale at $18 (before GST) in selected book stores, including @kinokuniya_singapore , Huggs-Epigram Coffee Bookshop, and @woodsinthebooks

The books can also be purchased at Singapore Children's Society's Bishan Office located at 9 Bishan Place #05-02 Junction 8 Office Tower Singapore 579837.

description:
Despite the bad weather conditions, the mood of students and teachers from Bukit Batok Secondary School were not dampened at all!⁣
⁣
In line with their annual Sports Day, #BBSS conducted a #fundraising walk - “No Shoe Day”, at Clementi Stadium on 26 April 2019 to raise funds for Singapore Children’s Society! As the name suggests, both students and teachers removed their shoes and went through obstacles such as acupressure mats while donating to the various collection boxes carried by student fundraisers. This event is one of the many holistic activities that the school engages, to #giveback to the community.⁣
⁣
We are grateful for the support and heartwarming responses from the enthusiastic students and teachers of #BBSS! If you or your school are interested in organising fundraising events for Singapore Children’s Society, drop us an email at frdda@childrenssociety.org.sg

description:
Are you aware of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child (UNCRC)? Our government submits a report to the United Nations every four to five years on our progress in advancing child rights. Watch the above clips to learn about the UNCRC, and how it is relevant to Singapore and to us. 
#ParenTIPS by Singapore Children’s Society is a topical parenting series on trends and research concerning children and youth. Through this series, we hope that parents and caregivers can pick up useful ideas and information on how to support their children's well-being and help them thrive.

description:
Gift your mum a gift that keeps on giving. How about donating in your mum’s name this Mother’s Day to Singapore Children’s Society?⁣
⁣
Show her your gratitude for providing the safe, stable and nurturing environment that you grew up in. #mothersday #gratitude #gifts⁣
⁣
Your meaningful gift will go a long way to support children and youth in need, who may not have enjoyed the same familial relations as you did.⁣
⁣
Donate in your mum’s name and uplift their lives now!  https://1000p.org.sg/get-involved
labels_str: person human poster advertisement hug

description:
#casestudy⁣
Mdm Ang* felt the financial strain of having to provide for her two school-going sons after her husband, who was formerly the breadwinner for the family, lost his mobility through a terrible fall. She was alone in her efforts to secure their basic needs while she battled with her own health issues and excruciating pain to take on a labour-intensive job to pay the bills.⁣
⁣
Thankfully, she found help and advice through the social workers from Yishun Family Service @ Children’s Society. Through the Centre’s assistance, Mdm Ang received financial assistance to support her children, and worked closely with our counsellors at Yishun Family Service @ Children’s Society to alleviate her stress.⁣
⁣
Why not lend a helping hand to all the strong and brave mummies out there this Mother’s Day? #mothersday #gratitude ⁣
⁣
Donate now. https://1000p.org.sg/get-involved⁣
⁣
*Name has been changed to protect the beneficiary’s identity

description:
#CaseStory⁣
It was a tumultuous time for Mr Joe*, a single father without a supportive family network, who only had the love from his children.⁣
⁣
Mr Joe made a wrong decision to borrow heavily from the loan sharks or illegal moneylenders, who hounded and left him scrambling to find a safe refuge for his children when he could not repay his debts. At wit’s end, Mr Joe sought help from Singapore Children’s Society. His children were admitted to Sunbeam Place @ Children's Society temporarily, and were protected from the harassment of the loan sharks while Mr Joe tried to clear his outstanding debts. Our staff members at Sunbeam Place @ Children's Society focused on caring for the children and worked closely with their school teachers and counsellor.⁣
⁣
On Good Friday, give an act of love by donating to support children, youth and families in need. Help them now >> https://1000p.org.sg/get-involved⁣
⁣
*Name has been changed to protect the beneficiary's identity⁣
*Photo credit: Freepik

description:
#DidyouknowSgChildrenSoc works closely with the youth, their families and support systems to rehabilitate and encourage youth towards a crime-free and prosocial lifestyle?⁣
⁣
Every Tuesday at the Youth Court, our team of social service practitioners screen complaints from parents who are considering pursing a Beyond Parental Control (BPC) order against their child. They will hear the parents' complaints and provide them with necessary information to aid them in their decision making. ⁣
⁣
Thus far, most cases involve running away from home, smoking and other undesirable activities. If you wish to find out more about the programme, drop us an email at bpc@childrensociety.org.sg
labels_str: person human hand finger

description:
No one should have to choose between death and financial hardship. ⁣
⁣
This #WorldHealthDay, help us ensure more children, youth, and families in need receive all the support they need to emerge triumph from a medical crisis.⁣
⁣
When you donate to Singapore Children’s Society, you are helping our beneficiaries get the attention and care they require. Our social workers work extensively with the community to help them apply for financial assistance and other subsidies, so they can cope with living expenses surrounding a medical emergency.⁣
⁣
Healthcare is a basic human right. #HealthForAll Help us to help our beneficiaries >> https://1000p.org.sg/get-involved⁣
⁣
*Photo credit: Pexels.com

description:
We are happy to have Assoc Prof @muhammadfaishalibrahim, Senior Parliamentary Secretary, Ministry of Social and Family Development & Ministry of Education, launch our 29th Project CABIN – Chillbox at Meridian Secondary School this morning.

Started in 1994, Project CABIN is a secondary school-based drop-in facility which encourages the development of character and life skills. CABINs provide a positive and conducive environment for youth after school hours which allows our youth workers to reach out to youth more effectively as students spend the bulk of their time in school. Besides organising fun-filled activities, the youth workers also conduct life skills workshops and training courses, as well as provide emotional support for students in need.

Started in 1994, Project CABIN is a secondary school-based drop-in facility which encourages the development of character and life skills. CABINs provide a positive and conducive environment for youth after school hours which allows our youth workers to reach out to youth more effectively as students spend the bulk of their time in school. Besides organising fun-filled activities, the youth workers also conduct life skills workshops and training courses, as well as provide emotional support for students in need.

description:
We invited our donors to one of our four youth drop-in centres @vox.44cc earlier in the month to mingle with our beneficiaries. They saw for themselves what goes on at the centre and were even treated to delicious snacks specially prepared by our youth!⁣
⁣
Here is what one of our donors, Mr Raymond Wee, Director of Lemongrass House Singapore Pte Ltd has to say: “Now, I have a better understanding of the holistic services provided by Singapore Children’s Society, and the roles and responsibilities the centre offers the youth. Being able to mingle with the social workers and the youth have been very fruitful for me. It is a good sharing session about the Society and also experiencing what @vox.44cc does.”

description:
As a self-funded charity organisation, we have to raise funds to support the many programmes and services that we run for our beneficiaries. Having launched our online fundraising platform last year called Give2Children (www.childrensociety.org.sg/g2c), we hope to enhance the spirit of giving through the platform, where you will have the creative space to run your own campaigns, for a good cause!⁣
⁣
Because individually, we might not have a lot to give. But together, our combined efforts will make a difference in the lives of our future generation.⁣
#givingiscaring #nonprofit #support #children
labels_str: clothing apparel person human evening dress fashion robe gown female skirt woman dress

description:
It takes women from every level of the society to create a balanced environment that fosters growth for all. With opportunities presented in the society, they make informed decisions that impact not only themselves, but their children too. Education plays a big part here.⁣
⁣
Mrs Tan* was a housewife dependent on her husband. However she divorced him as he was abusive and had to raise her seven children single-handedly. As she did not receive much education, she had trouble looking for a job to raise her children. At wit’s end, Mrs Tan turned to Yishun Family Service @ Children's Society for help.⁣
⁣
Thankfully, the social workers at the Centre helped her to apply for subsidies to support her children's education. They also equipped her with parenting and financial literacy skills. Since the Society’s inception, the programmes and services have evolved over time to support more children via avenues such as parenting help for single mothers, sexual abuse awareness and more.⁣
⁣
Support the work that we do by liking this post today! #IWD2019 #womensday #casestory⁣
⁣
*Name has been changed to protect the beneficiary's identity⁣
*Photo credit: Canva

description:
#DidyouknowSgChildrenSoc has a drop-in centre for both children and youth in the west? JYC @ Children’s Society reaches out to beneficiaries in two different age groups: DEN @ JYC reaches out to children aged 9 to 12 while GIG @ JYC reaches out to youth aged 13 to 18.⁣
⁣
Our social workers and counsellors engage daily with the youth, building up trust and rapport between them. This helps them open up and share with us their challenges and difficulties they are facing. Through this engagement process, our staff are then able to provide the necessary intervention to them.⁣
⁣
Sometimes, all it takes is a little patience and time to enter the world of our children, growing with them :)

description:
Chinese New Year is a time where families come together and celebrate the festivities. However, not all children get to experience this.⁣
⁣
6-year-old Tim* is a resident of Sunbeam Place @ Children’s Society. He comes from a single-parent family and his mother had returned to her home country to look after another family member. While he remained hopeful that his mother would return one day, he knew deep down that it would not happen so soon. Meanwhile, our social workers at the residential home worked hard to ensure that he does not miss out on education and a proper childhood.⁣
⁣
Help us, to help children like Tim to receive the love that they’ve always yearned for. Gift an Ang Bao this Chinese New Year so we can continue to care for more children alike.⁣
⁣
You can help by coming onboard our 1000 Philanthropists programme. Find out more:  www.1000p.org.sg⁣
⁣
*Name has been changed to protect the beneficiary's identity.

description: Taking care of a young child can feel a little overwhelming at times. Our series of parenting guides provides bite-sized information for parents and caregivers on child development milestones, and helpful tips on how to cope with challenging situations. The guides are available at $3 per copy. To purchase a copy, please email us at info@childrensociety.org.sg

description:
Children in their teenage years tend to be easily distracted and fall into bad company if they are misguided by their peers. In Children’s Society, we have 4 drop-in centres catered to children and youth to keep them away from the road of delinquency. ⁣
⁣
To read on more about how we engage the youth, click on the link in our bio.⁣
⁣
*Photo is for illustration purposes only. Photo credit: Freepik

Now that you are aware of our Tinkle Friend programme, we are excited to inform you that we are recruiting Tinkle Friend volunteers! If you enjoy chatting with children and have experience interacting with children, we want you! Sign up with us now at www.childrensociety.org.sg/volunteer-join

#DidyouknowSgChildrenSoc runs a national toll-free helpline for primary school children who need a listening ear? ⁣⁣
If you know of any lonely and distressed children who need to talk to someone, please encourage them to call our helpline (1800 2744 788) or chat with us online at www.tinklefriend.sg !

description:
Care and attention are vital for development of a child’s growth. Sometimes, children can be neglected due to parents’ busy work schedule, or simply lacking the means to raise a child.⁣
⁣
Student Care @ Children’s Society provides an after school care service for primary school children from low-income, single-parent and/or distressed families who are left at home without adult supervision. It is located within the Henderson neighbourhood and conducts programmes such as Choo Choo Train which aims to instil good character values through interactive games and activities for our children.⁣
⁣
To date, we have 12 service centres across the island offering programmes and services for children, youth and families in need.

description:
#CaseStory⁣
7-year-old Nina* and her younger siblings were often left to their own devices since young. Her father was retrenched and her mother suffered from depression. Thankfully, Nina and her siblings were referred to Student Care @ Children’s Society, where they received after school care in a nurturing environment.⁣
⁣
After she has graduated from the Centre, she returned as a volunteer to give back to our Society in hopes of impacting the lives of other children, like how our social workers have impacted hers.⁣
⁣
It warms our hearts to see children such as Nina, who wants to carry on the spirit of love. This motivates us to do even better at our craft. #givingback⁣
⁣
*Name has been changed to protect the beneficiary’s identity.⁣
*Photo credit: Pexels

description:
Come join us on Saturday, 26 January 2019, as @opbrokenwing will be happening in support of our youth centres - JYC @ Children's Society, @roundboxcentre, @thefortatchildrensociety and @vox.44cc ⁣
⁣
The event aims to bring together people from all walks of life – fitness enthusiasts from different gyms and disciplines, the young (from age 8), the old (to age 72), and the adaptive – all united with a common purpose to Fight for Hope for our forgotten youth. Be part of #OBW2019 as an athlete or sponsor by registering at www.operationbrokenwing.com today!

description:
Having highlighted the risks and dangers of social media, what are some of the steps we can take to help our children manage issues that may arise?

In our last series, we offer practical tips on how you can support your child as they explore and navigate the online world.

description:
In the last series, we saw the reasons why our children go online. Now, let us look at the safety risks and blind spots as children navigate through social media and gaming apps. 
This series is referenced from a UK report "Life in 'Likes': Children’s Commissioner report into social media use among 8-12 year olds".

description:
The school holidays are finally here! In this digital environment, our tech-savvy children are very likely to be spending more time on social media. Are you concerned about your child's safety online? 
In the first of our three-part series, we look at what children use social media for and their understanding of safety online. This series is referenced from a UK report "Life in 'Likes’: Children’s Commissioner report into social media use among 8-12 year olds”.

description: Our guest speaker Assoc Prof Teo You Yenn, Associate Professor and Head of Sociology at Nanyang Technological University, spoke about Growing up in an Unequal Society this morning at our 12th Singapore Children's Society Lecture at the Singapore Chinese Cultural Centre. She discussed the importance of situating the experiences of children and their families in the broader social context.

description:
Welcome back to our #CSCturns10 series! In this fourth post, we have gathered 10 tips to express love for your child, referenced from Gary Chapman and Dr Ross Campbell's "The 5 Love Languages of Children". It is important to note that these should be done unconditionally i.e. not as a reward. Stay tuned for our last two posts as we explore 10 tips for safe online usage for children and 10 things children want adults to know!

#singaporechildrensociety #sgchildrensoc #child #children #parenting #childrenwellbeing #emotionalwellbeing #socialwellbeing #psychologicalwellbeing #5lovelanguages #5lovelanguagesofchildren
labels_str: text

Stay tuned for our last two posts as we explore 10 tips for safe online usage for children and 10 things children want adults to know!

#singaporechildrensociety #sgchildrensoc #child #children #parenting #childrenwellbeing #emotionalwellbeing #socialwellbeing #psychologicalwellbeing #5lovelanguages #5lovelanguagesofchildren

description:
"While bullying and its impacts often tend to manifest itself overtly, the emotional and mental consequences are far more severe and lasting. Therefore, bullying should be snipped in the bud as early as possible,” said V Janani, a year 3 global studies major from National University of Singapore after attending a Bully-Free sharing session recently.

To find out more, please visit www.bullyfree.sg. You can also follow us on @scs.bullyfree.sg

description:
Are you embarrassed to talk to your child about sexuality? You are not alone! Many parents also have concerns about teaching their children body safety skills. Here we address the five common concerns that parents face. You'll find that it's not that difficult to start the conversation with your child today.
This is the second of our #teachbodysafety series. Refer to our bio for our first series. Look out for our final series next Thursday!

description:
Child sexual abuse is not the easiest topic to discuss with our children, perhaps because we don’t know where to start or how much to teach. The team behind KidzLive, our child sexual abuse prevention programme, is here to share some tips!

Over the next few weeks, we will be addressing common concerns parents have about teaching body safety skills, and highlighting the body safety messages we should relate to our children. Watch this space! In the meantime, find out more from our KidzLive booklet with our link in bio! #teachbodysafety

Watch this space! In the meantime, find out more from our KidzLive booklet with our link in bio! #teachbodysafety

Sometimes, we can change someone else’s life forever by being generous in a small way. 
Be the change you wish to see in the world and start impacting lives today. Donate now: https://childrensociety.give.asia/reunion. #Caringforthefuture #makeadifference

description:
65th Anniversary #Throwback: Do you know, our bubbly blue friend Tinkle Friend has turned 33? Tinkle Friend Helpline (1800 2744 788), a national toll-free helpline for primary school children, was first introduced to children who needed a listening ear in November 1984. In 2014, we started providing Tinkle Friend Online Chat service (www.tinklefriend.com) to children as we evolved with technology. Manned by trained staff and volunteers, both services provide support, advice and information to lonely and distressed children especially when their parents or main caregivers are unavailable. 
Beaten by her parents and bullied by her elder brother, nine-year-old Jenny* felt alone and unloved. She turned to the web, and found comfort in Tinkle Friend, who was willing to listen and give her support and advice. Jenny was eventually referred to her school counsellor, and was grateful for the help rendered. 
There may be many more Jennys out there who need our help. Help us today so that we can change someone’s tomorrow. Give now: http://bit.ly/2u2GeM3. #Caringforthefuture *Name has been changed to protect the identity of the child. #children #charity #makeadifference #donate

description:
65th Anniversary #Throwback: More than 200 volunteers participated in our Flag Day three weeks ago. This year, our Flag Day was held at ERC Institute SG, where individuals, students and the wider community converged to garner donations to support our cause. 
A team of superheroes also rallied and canvassed for our children in need at Dhoby Ghaut. 
Ms Goh Jiayi, one of our volunteers from Singapore Polytechnic Civil Defence Lionhearters Club, said: “My most memorable experience is when we passed by a small construction site and asked if the foreign workers would like to donate and help the children in need, they all reached into their pockets, smiled and donated without any hesitation.” She added: “This experience has changed my perspective of doing good. I believe that it is not easy for them to earn a living and support their families, but they were willing to help others who are in need.” Thank you all for making a difference！❤️ #CaringfortheFuture #makeadifference
labels_str: person human boy clothing apparel face advertisement poster flyer paper brochure

description:
It’s World Gratitude Day Let us take time to reflect on the positive aspects of our lives and spread the happiness to someone by paying it forward. 
Help our children in need today by making a small donation to support our programmes at our 11 service centres and help our children in need now. http://bit.ly/2u2GeM3.  #MakeADifference #celebrate #charity

description:
The Mid-Autumn Festival carries special meaning as a day for family reunions. It brings joy, love and warmth to families. 
Not every child has the privilege of a proper education and childhood. Under the care of our social workers, children in need are able to receive after school care services and proper education. 
This Mid-Autumn Festival, warm the hearts of our children, spread the love and help build a brighter future for our children by making a small donation today. http://bit.ly/1rWy9fW. #MakeADifference #children #donate #Caringforthefuture

description:
Check out the photo taken by our budding photographer and @roundboxcentre youth, Md Shahrul Nizam. His photo was unveiled during the official launch of My Toa Payoh, Our Stories by MP Mr Chee Hong Tat. Said Shahrul, "I like this photograph because it shows how beautiful Toa Payoh night view can be. From the top of the newest building in the neighbourhood, you can really see almost everything of Toa Payoh, buildings of old and new, and tall and short." Follow @ourtoapayohstories and discover more beautiful shots of #ToaPayoh.
#MTPOS #RoundBox #YouthSG #SGphotography #Singapore

description:
We need your help for Flag Day 2017! Together, we can make a difference and here’s how you can help our children in need:
Make an outright donation
Purchase our car decals at $30/set (6 assorted designs)
Adopt a Flag Bag at $68 each
Volunteer with us on Wednesday, 6 September at ERC Institute SG
Organise an internal collection
For more information, please contact Ms Jayne Toh on 6273 2010 or jtoh@childrensociety.org.sg. #Caringforthefuture
labels_str: text flyer brochure advertisement poster paper

description:
What better way to increase your child’s motivation towards education than through playing games, making new friends and engaging in fun activities? 
This September, come join us at our camp to help your child see the relevance of education in their daily lives and their future aspirations. 
The camp gives children aged 7 to 8 the opportunity to bond with new friends and learn in a creative environment. A trip to Kidzania Singapore is included too. 
Details as follows: 
Date:  Wednesday and Thursday, 6 and 7 September
Time:  9.30am – 4.30pm (Day 1)  9.30am – 5.30pm (Day 2)
Venue:  Singapore Children’s Society, Children Service Centre
Cost: $20 (inclusive of an outing to Kidzania Singapore) 
Sign up now!
labels_str: text flyer brochure advertisement poster paper

description: My Toa Payoh Our Stories, is a RoundBox @ Singapore Children’s Society community-based initiative supported by HDB that aims to allow the youth to be able to showcase Toa Payoh the way they see it. From 12 August to 28 December 2017, nine selected photographs taken by our RoundBox youth will be put up on display around Toa Payoh, forming an exhibition trail where audiences can embark to not only discover the photographs, but also one of the oldest estates in Singapore. The project will be officially launched by MP Mr Chee Hong Tat on 12 August 2017, 9.30am at the open field next to Toa Payoh Market as part of Toa Payoh West CC’s National Day celebrations. Come spend your Saturday morning with us and celebrate the start of the exhibition as well as our Nation’s Birthday! For more information, follow @OURTOAPAYOHSTORIES on Instagram now! #RoundBox #YouthSG #MTPOS #SGPhotography #Singapore #ToaPayoh
labels_str: ballet dance person human ballerina

description:
65th Anniversary #Throwback: After a successful Charity Gala Dinner with the fairy tale theme last year, expect nothing less than a glamorous affair at our Charity Gala Dinner this year. Themed ‘Retro’, the Gala Dinner will see Broadway Beng as the main performing act. 
Details as follows: 
Date: Thursday, 19 October 2017
Time: 6.30pm (Cocktail Session), Guests to be seated by 7.00pm
Venue: Shangri-La Hotel, Singapore (Island Ballroom) 
Invite your business partners and friends to support our cause. Table/seat donations, event sponsorships and outright donations will be entitled to 2.5 times tax-deduction. 
For more information, please contact Ms Lee Wen Ting or Ms Yasmin Niepelt on 6273 2010 or email wtlee@childrensociety.org.sg / yniepelt@childrensociety.org.sg. #Caringforthefuture

National Day is just around the corner. As we fly our flag up high and celebrate our nation’s success, let us not forget about giving back and caring for our children in need. 
You can help to transform their lives and support our ongoing efforts to bring relief and happiness to them.

description:
65th Anniversary #Throwback: Some 3,000 participants joined our Walk for Our Children last Sunday to help raise funds for our children in need. Here’s a shout-out to our Guest-of-Honour, Mr Ong Ye Kung, Minister for Education (Higher Education and Skills) & Second Minister for Defence, all our donors, sponsors, volunteers and colleagues for making our Walk a success! 
We have more exciting events lined up for you as we celebrate our 65th anniversary. Follow us @ sgchildrensoc on Instagram and Facebook for more updates on our upcoming 65th Anniversary Conference on 24 and 25 November. 
Missed our Walk? You can still support us here: http://bit.ly/2eNjucd. #WOC17 #SgChildrenSoc65 #rethinksuccess #children #makeadifference

description:
Capturing the beautiful moments and happy faces of families at our superhero-themed photo booth. Join us at our 35 carnival stalls including our superhero-themed photo booth, food and game stalls now. You can purchase your carnival coupons at our coupon stalls. 
Don’t miss the Meet & Greet session with our mascots from Star Wars and Marvel Adventures at 11.30am! #WOC17 #children #event #makeadifference

description:
Walk for Our Children is happening now! Participation in our walkathon is free so what are you waiting for? Come join us for a meaningful walk at Chinese Garden. 
Like us @ sgchildrensoc on Instagram and Facebook, snap a picture at our event and include our hashtag #WOC17 to stand a chance to win our exclusive 65th anniversary commemorative pack. #children #event #makeadifference

description:
Make the most of your weekend and get ready to walk and bond with your family and friends at Walk for Our Children tomorrow!
Rain or shine, our carnival and stage activities will still go on. So don’t forget to pack your umbrellas and ponchos and have a great day out with your loved ones this weekend! Parking space is limited, so you are encouraged to take public transport.

Event Details:
Date: Sunday, 30 July 2017
Time: 8.30am – 12.30pm
Venue: Chinese Garden (Dragon & Phoenix Court)

Follow us on Facebook and Instagram @ sgchildrensoc for live event updates tomorrow.

More info @ www.walkforourchildren.sg. #WOC17 #makeadifference #children #event

description:
Do you know that people in Singapore walk about 5,000 steps every day? Make each step you take more meaningful today and register for our Walk for Our Children event at www.walkforourchildren.sg

Purchase your carnival coupons at $20 each and stand a chance to win lucky draw prizes worth about $4,000 including a 4D3N cruise sponsored by Star Cruises and $300 Courts shopping vouchers. #WOC17 #children #charity #makeadifference

Official Media Production: Dreambox Studio

description:
We’re just one week away from our annual Walk for Our Children event! 
Snap photos at our superhero-themed photo booth, get your caricature drawn and have fun at our game stalls with your loved ones. Don't forget to put your smile on when you spot our roving photographers at the event! 
With registration filling up fast, don’t miss out the opportunity to spend a meaningful weekend with your loved ones. More info @ www.walkforourchildren.sg. #WOC17 #children #charity #event

description:

1. Try to set aside time on a regular basis to do something fun with your child
2. Never give an order, request or command without being able to enforce it at the time
3. Be consistent in the rewards and punishments to your child 
Stay tuned for more tips coming up next Friday!

description:
How do your children feel about themselves?

Our colleagues from Talks and Workshops Programmes Centre have recently imparted tips to the students of Yishun Secondary School, on how to feel good about themselves:

1. Give yourself 3 compliments in a day!
2. List 3 things in your day which made you happy!
3. Get active in a sport!
4. Surround yourself with people who appreciate you for who you are!
5. Tell someone if you need help!

Schools that would like to have more information on programmes to increase the social and emotional competencies of primary and secondary school students, please contact Ms Hidayah on 6753 7331 or at nhfauzan@childrensociety.org.sg.

description:
What are you doing on the last day of 2015? Why not end the year with a good deed?

Our social worker Kate Ofiaza, from Family Service Centre (Yishun) has recently helped a family regain financial independence, after the family encountered difficulties making ends meet. Having approached the Centre for help, Kate rendered emotional support and ad-hoc food rations for Alinah’s family, equipped Alinah with problem solving and stress management skills, strategised a plan for clearing her debts, motivated her to provide emotional support to her husband, linked Alinah with job fairs and provided school pocket money fund for her daughter. After receiving help and being re-employed in December last year, Alinah’s family has now regained financial independence, and is able to manage their finances more effectively.

Kudos to Kate for extending her help! 
#singaporechildrenssociety #familyservicecentreyishun #lastdayof2015

description:
Peer influence and peer pressure can be both positive and negative. Some commonly seen negative peer pressure include grouping together to ostracise particular classmates or going after the latest gadgets in order to feel belonged to a group. On the other hand, positive peer pressure can include influencing the child to study together or encouraging the child to help the less fortunate by participating in voluntary work. 
Share with us how you think parents can support their children in dealing with negative peer pressure!

description:
More than 30 parents of My First Skool (Jurong West) mastered the art of rewarding their children through a Positive Parenting Talk. 
Rewarding your children can reinforce positive behaviours in them and to make them feel good about themselves! One way of rewarding is to do so verbally such as praising them for their good behaviour. For example, give recognition when they assist in clearing the dishes together with you after meal times.

Share with us on the ways you reward your children! 😄
#singaporechildrenssociety #myfirstskool

description:
Children face many difficult and stressful situations during exam periods. We believe that every child has the capacity to deal with such challenges. Tinkle Friend is interested in gathering tips on how your children overcome these challenges. Invite your children to share their tips with us and stand a chance to win Popular vouchers! 
Simply e-mail us at tinklefriend@childrensociety.org.sg or write to us at:
BUZZ Tinkle Friend
Singapore Children’s Society (Student Service Hub)
91 Henderson Road #01-112
Singapore 150091 
Please indicate your full name, age, and address in your entry. We will feature the best entries on our Facebook page and in the next issue of our BUZZ newsletter for primary school students. Submit your entries by 30 November, 2015!
#singaporechildrenssociety #tinklefriend #buzz

description:
Where do you hang out or #chill as a #youth? 
Our youth beneficiaries found their place to relax at Youth Centre (Jurong). “I feel happy because I can ‘chill’ with friends and participate in many fun activities,” says Teck Siang, 17, who is a member at our Youth Centre (Jurong). “The staff at the Centre helped me to become more confident, caring and helpful.” Fellow youth member, Hanis, 17, adds that the friends he made at the Centre draws him to keep coming back. 
We wish you all a happy Youth Day!

#happyyouthday #youthday #SingaporeChildrensSociety #sgig #singapore #jurong
